header_summary:
A forthcoming meeting aims to delineate the activation parameters for Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) 119, urging participants to review pertinent documents and previous discussions to facilitate constructive dialogue. The session, scheduled in the IRC Channel: ctv-csfs-activation on libera.chat, will focus on developing an activation client for BIP 119, underscoring the significance of community involvement in the proposal's refinement process ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CALiT-Zqo-gRCeMDd2VtmXL7Ox31OT3pFmsfXQ5mq6SzeuFnMzg@mail.gmail.com/T/#u#me7eb4a1d593c073163e2163e717798c4a62d8a8e)).

In a separate discussion, two Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs)—BUDS (Bitcoin Unified Data Standard) and segOP (Segregated OP_RETURN)—have been introduced for community review. BUDS seeks to create a structured taxonomy for transaction data, while segOP proposes a method to enhance data embedding efficiency in transactions. These proposals aim to bolster the Bitcoin ecosystem's functionality without altering its consensus mechanism, highlighting the importance of peer feedback in the development process ([BUDS GitHub](https://github.com/defenwycke/bip-buds), [segOP GitHub](https://github.com/defenwycke/bip-segop)).

Additionally, discussions have delved into optimizing network traffic management for Bitcoin nodes and the potential of segregating different types of network messages to enhance security and efficiency. Proposals under consideration include the use of new Remote Procedure Calls (RPCs) for scheduling transactions, which could offer users more control over transaction timings and contribute to a more streamlined, secure blockchain network. These conversations reflect a broader community effort to address the challenges posed by the Bitcoin network's growth and the evolving demands on its infrastructure ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/scheduled-delayed-transaction-broadcast/2148/3)).

Lastly, the debate around the preservation of the 80,000 signature operations limit with the Taproot update, despite concerns over its sufficiency, emphasizes a cautious approach to Bitcoin development. This conservatism, aimed at ensuring network stability and compatibility, invites a reevaluation of existing constraints in light of technological advances and changing network demands, suggesting that the community continues to prioritize a balanced approach to scaling and security ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/benchmarking-bitcoin-script-evaluation-for-the-varops-budget-great-script-restoration/2094/12)).

recent_posts.title: Request for early peer review of two BIP drafts (BUDS and segOP)
recent_posts.summary:
- Two Bitcoin Improvement Proposals, BUDS and segOP, have been published for peer review.
- BUDS aims to structure transaction data, while segOP proposes a consensus change for data embedding.
- Feedback is sought on the drafts' clarity and potential improvements, emphasizing community collaboration.

recent_posts.title: Splitting more block, addr and tx classes of network traffic
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin nodes are evolving with segregated network traffic to enhance efficiency and security.
- Segregation improvements include outbound block-relay-only connections and potential signaling enhancements.
- Innovative solutions and ongoing discussions aim to optimize Bitcoin's network traffic management and security.

recent_posts.title: BIP The Cat - Draft discussion
recent_posts.summary:
- The proposal aims to limit Bitcoin's non-monetary uses, stirring debate due to its novelty.
- Seeking global feedback, the initiator emphasizes open critique for the proposal's refinement.
- The proposer, confirming their human origin, invites rigorous community review to improve the initiative.

recent_posts.title: Scheduled (Delayed) Transaction Broadcast
recent_posts.summary:
- The email explores obscuring transaction creation times on blockchain for better security.
- It introduces `schedulerawtransaction` RPC for scheduling transactions with certain conditions.
- Discusses the challenges and impacts of integrating these features on blockchain performance.

recent_posts.title: Benchmarking Bitcoin Script Evaluation for the Varops Budget (Great Script Restoration)
recent_posts.summary:
- The 80,000 sig ops limit in Taproot reflects a cautious design choice for Bitcoin's evolution.
- The approach maintains stability by adhering to historical precedents set by SegWit updates.
- Discussions urge a reevaluation of sig ops limits in response to Bitcoin's technological advancements.

active_posts.title: Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- The analysis targets Bitcoin's vulnerabilities, suggesting improvements for network security and performance.
- It proposes adjustments to mining difficulty and limits on legacy transactions to enhance stability.
- Community input is encouraged, highlighting debates on block size and technical standardization efforts.

active_posts.title: Dust Expiry: Clean the UTXO set from spam
active_posts.summary:
- A soft-fork proposes age-based expiration for dust outputs to reduce UTXO spam.
- UTXO set size doubled since 2023 due to spam, affecting half of its contents.
- The proposal aims for community input to address spam by making old, small outputs unspendable.

active_posts.title: Gossip Observer: New project to monitor the Lightning P2P network
active_posts.summary:
- The project aims to analyze the Lightning gossip network, highlighting a reduced convergence delay.
- Observations include a significant message transmission from a minority of peers, impacting network efficiency.
- Future plans involve expanding infrastructure to study gossip spread and engaging the community for further analysis.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP - Dead Man's Switch
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- About 4 million of the mined Bitcoins are lost due to unknown private keys.
- A proposed Bitcoin Improvement Proposal introduces a dead man's switch for dormant addresses.
- This mechanism could increase miner rewards by accounting for expired Bitcoins.

today_in_history_posts.title: Peer Selection
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Making outgoing channels private maximizes profits but restricts income from fees.
- Private channels prevent loss from connectivity issues but increase onchain fees.
- Accepting incoming channels and routing attempts enhances network participation and potential earnings.

today_in_history_posts.title: Timewarp attack 600 second grace period
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Matt Corallo's proposal focuses on Bitcoin mining's `nTime` rolling limits.
- The timewarp fix allows a 600-second backward `nTime` adjustment on testnet4.
- Discussions advocate for a two-hour grace period and limiting `nTime` rolling.
